junityahoo@... wrote:
> 
> 
>  > > Is it so wrong to want to instantiate a test with some parameters and
>  > > automatically run the tests on it?
>  >
>  > No, but JUnit was not designed that way.
> 
> But I keep feeling like there must be a way to get this behaviour out of 
> JUnit
> and I am just missing it.  I'm willing to accept that it is a problem 
> with me
> rather than JUnit.  Is there something about my outlook on testing that 
> I need
> to refine?  I am surprised that data driven testing like this is not 
> supported,
> as it seems like soemthign that would be used a lot.  What is the reasoning
> behind JUnit not beign designed for this, and is there soemthign that I 
> can do
> to acheive what I want while still keeping with JUnit's design goals.

You're welcome to feel that way; I won't press the issue anymore. It's 
entirely possible that all the very smart people who've been working 
with JUnit since 1999 have missed what you'll eventually figure out. I 
have to allow for that possibility. Still, if I were you, I think I 
might take some stock in what someone with experience has to say.

That said, highly data-driven testing /is/ supported by JUnit, as long 
as you don't care about how it reports tests in test runs. You could 
simply write this test:

testAlgorithm
     data = some array
     foreach (item in data)
         doTest(item)

This works just fine, except:

1. If the algorithm fails for the 5th row of data, you'll never know 
what happens with the 6th row, because the test will fail

2. Although you're really running n tests, JUnit will report it as only 1.

If you don't care about these so-called limitations, then you're done.

Now you /can/ run all your test*() methods for each row in a List of 
fixture objects, but I don't want to get into the details of how until I 
have time to sit down and write an article about it. Today's not the day.

Finally, you were earlier talking about something like instantiating and 
running a test from some other test. JUnit /definitely/ don't work that 
way. Don't even bother. Tests do not run other tests; that's why we have 
test runners.

>  > This is a different problem from the one you described before, so it's a
>  > different one from what I tried to help you solve.
> 
> Yes, that is why I tried to describe it better.  I really appreciate 
> your taking
> the time to understand what I am saying and help me.  I bought your book

> Alright I will look into FitNesse like you suggested.  But I still feel like

> failed to

Understand that what I'm about to say is a little harsh, but it's true. 
I hope we're all mature enough to take it in the spirit in which it's given:

  * A sign of maturity in any profession is when we recognize the 
limitations of tools and work around them, often by finding better 
tools. To try hopelessly to reshape every problem so that one tool 
solves it is wishful thinking. It's a phase we all go through and have 
to get through.

Four years ago, I was you, hoping that JUnit would do everything 
including massage my feet when I was tired.

I hope Fit/FitNesse helps you solve the problem in a nicer way. If not, 
then just wait for my next recipe: "Parameterized Test Suite". :)

Take care.
